<html><body><div><div><p><span class="dateline">PROVIDENCE, R.I. (WJAR) — </span>The city of Providence on Monday released records of its response to the <a href="https://turnto10.com/news/brown-university-shooting" target="_blank">shooting at Brown University</a> that left two people dead and nine injured.</p><p>Among the records is a 20-minute video comprised of bodycam footage that shows the police response to the school after the shooting was reported on Dec. 13.</p><p></p><p class="HTMLEmbed_htmlEmbed__Hy4rB"></p><p>The video is redacted. Black boxes appear in the video to obscure some images.</p><p>It shows a chaotic scene where no suspect is in custody.</p><p></p><p class="HTMLEmbed_htmlEmbed__Hy4rB"></p><p>In addition to the bodycam footage, there were also <a href="https://www.providenceri.gov/brown-shooting-apra/" target="_blank">official incident reports</a> by the Providence Police Department and the Providence Fire Department.</p><p>The police file is an incident report that lists charges, the suspect and his victims, then has a report or summary written by an officer.</p><p></p><div class="ImageEmbed_imageEmbed__5mYLo"><img alt="Screenshot of law enforcement responding to the Brown University shooting in December 2025. (Providence PD)" class="ImageEmbed_image__qZBo_" src="/resources/media2/16x9/1153/986/54x0/90/26462533-fbe3-4ec3-a213-746ab65fecf9-ScreenshotoflawenforcementrespondingtotheBrownUniversityshootinginDecember2025.ProvidencePD.jpg"><div class="ImageEmbed_caption__gAtoE"><p>Screenshot of law enforcement responding to the Brown University shooting in December 2025. (Providence PD)</p></div></div><p>In a Monday morning press availability, Providence Mayor Brett Smiley said the release was the full response to all public records requests. </p><p>The 20-minute video was from only one officer.</p><p>Smiley said the one video showed the scope of the response. </p><p>The mayor said he was trying to balance satisfying the public records request while not traumatizing the victims and the community. </p><p>The administration said it had delayed the release of the records until after a vigil over the weekend. </p><p>Smiley said numerous family members asked him not to release any of the records. </p><p>There is also audio of incoming calls to the Providence Police Department and its dispatch disseminating that among officers.</p><p>In one of the recordings, the dispatcher says a call that reported about five shots and people running.</p><p>There is also audio from Brown University police confirming shots and attempting to find a victim.  In one audio recording, the suspect is described as wearing all black and a ski mask.</p><p></p><div class="ImageEmbed_imageEmbed__5mYLo"><img alt="Here is the map where the Providence Police Department concetrated its search following the Brown University shooting.  (Providence PD)" class="ImageEmbed_image__qZBo_" src="/resources/media2/16x9/1920/986/center/90/62a3a834-34a9-4a92-aa05-5f6b91f9da02-HereisthemapwheretheProvidencePoliceDepartmentconcetrateditssearchfollowingtheBrownUniversityshooting.ProvidencePD.png"><div class="ImageEmbed_caption__gAtoE"><p>Here is the map where the Providence Police Department concetrated its search following the Brown University shooting.  (Providence PD)</p></div></div><p>Included in the release were also the arrest affidavit, maps of the search, and images of the suspect that police released to the public during the search.</p><p>On Dec. 13, gunman Claudio Neves Valente, 48, entered a study session in a Brown academic building and opened fire on students, killing 19-year-old sophomore Ella Cook and 18-year-old freshman MukhammadAziz Umurzokov and wounding nine others.</p><p>A newly released police incident report reiterated the emotional moments law enforcement had previously shared about hospitalized victims responding to photos of the suspected shooter.</p><p>One victim “quickly froze, physically pushed back” and began crying and shaking as she confirmed the image matched the person who shot her. Another victim “took a deep breath, shut his eyes, changed his breathing pattern and confirmed that the shooter he saw in the hallway appeared to be the person in the photos presented.”</p><p></p><div class="ImageEmbed_imageEmbed__5mYLo"><img alt="Col. Oscar Perez discusses the release of public records regarding the Brown University shooting. (WJAR){ }" class="ImageEmbed_image__qZBo_" src="/resources/media2/16x9/1360/986/0x20/90/ff9251ff-5350-4b58-8988-a0557a645901-oscarperez.jpg"><div class="ImageEmbed_caption__gAtoE"><p>Col. Oscar Perez discusses the release of public records regarding the Brown University shooting. (WJAR){ }</p></div></div><p>Authorities say Neves Valente, who had been a graduate student at Brown studying physics during the 2000-01 school year, also fatally shot Massachusetts Institute of Technology professor Nuno F.G. Loureiro at Loureiro’s Boston-area home.</p><p>Neves Valente, who had attended school with Loureiro in Portugal in the 1990s, was found dead days after the shooting in a New Hampshire storage facility.</p><p>The Justice Department has since said Neves Valente <a href="https://turnto10.com/news/brown-university-shooting/brown-university-shooting-mit-professor-videos-planned-attack-motive-unclear-us-attorney-for-massachusetts-department-of-justice-new-hampshire-storage-facility-january-6-2026" target="_blank">planned the attack for years</a> and left behind videos in which he confessed to the killings but gave no motive. The FBI recovered the electronic device containing the series of videos during a search of the storage facility where Neves Valente’s body was found.</p><p><em><strong>The Associated Press contributed to this report. </strong></em></p><p><em><strong><br></strong></em></p><p><br></p></div></div></body></html>
